instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cpu vcore stuck at 1.1V
threads.message:
Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had mild water damage. Board now turns on but cpuvcore hangs at 1.1V

What to check/ try first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cpu vcore stuck at 1.1V
threads.message:
Where was the spill?
Try first other RAM, one module at a time.
Clean the memory slots and inspect their solders close to the edges.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> has the correct value.
Check for corrosion around SPI chip <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and inspect all its traces and SPI termination resistors.
You can also try new BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cpu vcore stuck at 1.1V
threads.message:
Spill was just around lcd connector area.

Tried good ram one module at a time.

<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> already has the correct value.

No corrosion around SPI <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>

Tried new bios and SMC but still same problem.

What to check next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cpu vcore stuck at 1.1V
threads.message:
The PCH could got damaged by liquid.
Check all the lines which go from LCD connector to PCH; diode mode to ground.
Could also be a simple resistor, or even CPU.
Just in case, use good flux and heat PCH and CPU.
Be sure to get 25MHz from pin 9 of <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.
